Once through the village and have turned left at the Tjunction, there is a lovely little local restaurant serving suckling pig for about 2 dollars! Makes the long walk worthwhile!
Serene river walk. OK but not spectacular as how we expected. The area is however clean and serene. We loved its beautiful gorges and must have expected too much from the river size.

Serene, calm. Took the walk alone, without the guide, started from jalan kajeng, where my home stay was located, asked my hostess the direction and head off, north, brought my gps along and map just for safety... Started the walk, and throught the rice fields, then cross some bush and forest and it seemed i was entering a small valley, hills and high grounds to the left and right. For a while there seemed to be no more paddy fields to see but from my point of view, i was certain there is another way out through jalan campuhan. Went out to higher grounds on the left, and emerged into an even better landscape. Followed the trail met some locals, and along the way there's lots of cafe's warungs for stop and rest. Cant resist my self for a stop and some drinks. Nice drinks but don't put your expectation too high on the food. Check the price before sitting. The view and scene is worth a stop for a short break. Exit via jalan campuhan, and had a remarkable walk. Could see some mountains on the way but too cloudy to get a good picture of it.

Beautiful views. Do it early.. This is a beautiful walk with some amazing views and absolutely worth doing. Just make sure you do it early. We made the mistake of starting mid-afternoon and it was so hot and humid that it made the trek absolutely miserable.

Changing slowly. We have been doing the Campuan Ridge Walk for a number of years now. It is good to see that it still goes so many very positive reviews. There are some amazing river alley and rice field views along this walk and several places to stop, rest and have a cool drink. At the moment the large temple at Campuan is undergoing renovations/extensions so be careful as you go past some of the track is missing. I would advise everyone to do this walk before there is too much more building in the area by foreigners. Enjoy it while you can. Another recommendation is that, if you do want to stop for a cool drink, and you probably will, stop at one of the smaller shops on the way. By doing so you will pay half the price than at the cafe with the three thatched huts. The views thee are great, the food a bit expensive, but they have certainly learned how to hike up the price of drinks
The easy way. This is a lovely walk from the village of Keliki back to Ubud.Very scenic ,local artists on way. Get a bemo to Keliki then easy gradual walk back to Ubud.

Beautiful View, Reasonable Distance. It was easy to reach, very close to the main road (Jalan Raya Ubud). Beautiful view on the top of the hill. Reasonable trek and distance for inexperience trekker like me and my wife.

great walk. just did the frst 2-3 km walk up tothe cafe from the Ubud bridge and back again. Brilliant walk, even if we did it in the midday sun! Made itto the cafe with the tables in the rice paddies (look for 3 native style thatched huts after the path turns to a roadway) and had a well deserved limejuice and then turned around. Great scenes over the jungle valleys and then into the rice terraces. The way is also paved so easy walking (pathway is better than most of those in Ubud!)
Campuhan Walk. This is also a great walk with lots of views on both sides of the valley. Make sure you take a hat as it does get very hot on the walk. It is a long walk but worth it.

Beautiful walk. We went on this walk based on a recommendation from a relative. It did not let down. The bulk of the beauty is in the first 2k of the walk. We kept going into the village and found a lovely little cafe with 3 bales in a fish pond overlooking the rice terraces where we enjoyed a cold beer. On our walk we ran into a very friendly painter who wanted nothing more than to chat with us. It was terrific. There were lots of local high school kids going on a romantic walk.I'm not sure where the end of the walk is so I can't say that we finished it, but it was fantastic!
Lovely walk. A lovely walk along the ridge. Stop for a drink in the warung that you come to about 30-40 minutes into the walk. Lovely bales to sit in over the water with views over the rice fields.

good walk, but watch out in the wet!. Finally found this walk at long last and we did enjoy the walk and the woderful scenery, but is was raining and a bit slippery! so leave the walk till the sun shines.

Super mega amazing!. From Ubud town, along Jalan Sangingan, turn right to Ibah Warwick. Turn left and go down till you see school on the left and small shop on the right. If taking motorbike, you can park at the school compound. Just before the bridge, walk down (right side) to the step and stony path underneath the bridge. Follow the path and get ready for a super mega amazing experience.You will be served a delectable green lush tropical view along the way. Please don't sleep, stay awake as every second counts! The track is superb! and don't forget to bring small towel for your lovely sweat. After 2km trekking, you will see a big bungalow on the right. You have come to the end of the amazing experience but please don't stop! Continue another 1km walk for a refuel at Karsa Kafe before heading back. Yes, you need money to buy food and drink.You have two options to return; either walking via the same route as you come, 3km walk along Campuhan Ridge or walk for another 6 km ahead via village road OR you can get someone to send you back to Ubud at a small fee. I was offered at Rp.50,000 but I prefer walking back via Campuhan Ridge where I parked my motorbike.Please do this activity and you absolutely won't regret.

The Artists Walk. This walk was historically a inspiration for early artists in Ubud and remains one of the most spectacular ways to see a little of Ubud outside of the hassle of Monkey Forest Road. It is a easy walk from the top of the ridge down to the bottom but only takes a round trip of 40 minutes at a easy stroll. The hardest bit is the walk out of the river end but that soon makes way to a ridge top walk where you can see down to the river verges on both sides. I recommend making your way up to the Kokos Hotel for a refreshing drink before returning to the bottom again. You can park your scooters or car off the road at the bottom of the walk below the Ibah Resort lower car park entrance.

It's Beautiful. Honestly, at first when my friend asked me to walk with him to Campuhan Ridge i said no. He just told me it was a beautiful place, i didn't believe him. So, we went to there by bicycle and the road was steep. However, as i got to the ridge, i was stunned. Campuhan Ridge was beautiful! Very great view. I stopped at the narrow lane, took a rest, drink my mineral water and chatted with my friend. It was relaxing..If you want to walk/cycle in Campuhan Ridge, make sure you make it early in the morning, otherwise it would be so hot. And also, bring mineral water.

Alternate walk. With sore back, legs and fair skin we were reluctant to commit ourselves to the ridge walk in the sun but alternatively ended up doing a shorter walk through the rice fields from the end of Jalan Kajeng following the irrigation channels.quite shady for most of the way, passing sari organic and finishing on Jalan raya ubud not far from the bridge. We had to ask a few people along the way which way to go you get to a sharp fork on the trail which almost doubles back on itself on the other side of the irrigation channel, cross over the channel to head back to the main road direction rather than continuing up the valley. Wear cheap walking shoes as they will quite likely get wet and muddy and you'll probably want to ditch them before getting on the plane.

Great scenery behind Ubud. This walk is a great view behind the hustle and bustle of Ubuds main streets. Leave early if you are walking anytime around the wet season as the humidity will get to you. We only did the ridge to the retreat places but thus was enough to see life behind the scenes. There was locals cutting grass for the weaving and thatched roofs, school kids at the start being entrepreneurs asking for money and the labour of seeing the local temple being by built at the start of the walk is amazing ! Well with it. The ridge is around 4 klm there and return.

Outstanding. Outstanding walk, we loved every minute of it. Be sure to start out early morning to see the sun rise above the rice fields. There is a side walk cafe halfway where you can have a drink/rest.

Long walk. Started from ibah at 10am and saw many tourist on the way. Walk on the ridge is fairly easy on the paves. At the end of the greenery, you will enter a village and walk on a rocky road to karsa cafe. Had watermelon juice and a yummy cheese and tomato jaffle. The banana pancake was nothing fantastic. Continued on the rocky road until I hit the T junction tarred road and took a left turn. by then the noon heat was unbearable. The road winds around the village and be warned that its a steep slope of about 400m stretch (way steeper than the ridge). Nothing much to see with the usual shops along the road. From the T junction to neka museum at moderate pace took us about 1hr. Would not walk this route back again and suggest others to turn around and return from the ridge or take the transport from karsa cafe at rp 50k.

Beautiful Walk. This is one of the best walks in Ubud. You walk alone the top of the ridge. The ridge runs between to rivers that is why it is called Campuhan, Campur means mix and in this case the 2 rivers are mixing together. Its an easy walk. Some stairs but a well built path. It takes about 20 min to walk and then you have to come back unless you keep walk and ask the locals and it comes back in to Ubud. The long walk is about 2 hours. Worth going. Free.

Best if you're a bit fit. I've been to Ubud 8 times or more, and every time I visit I intend to do this hike. This year I finally made it, and felt quite proud when I got back to my room in Penestanan. You start from the temple that's way down below the Campuhan Bridge. They're renovating, and it's a bit hard to find the path, but someone will help. Then it's a long slow climb up through fields of elephant grass, used for thatching. It's immediately beautiful, as you walk through a sea of bright green with views across the ravines on both sides of the ridge. The path is paved with bricks most of the way, with the odd patch of dirt road. It's rather up and down, but not too demanding. Best to set out early though, before it gets too hot. Eventually you will come out onto the road from Payogan to Keliki village, which is narrow and quite busy...it's safer to walk on the right, facing on-coming traffic. The hardest part of this 8km trek was the steep dip down to the river and the really long climb back up the other side...I'm sure it was further up than down! I was offered a motorbike ride, but declined. My 64-year-old body relishes a challenge, and I am so aware that slow and steady wins the race. From the top of the hill, it's still quite a way into Ubud, and since it's all on the road, I think that when I do this hike again, I'll just walk to the end of the ridge and back. I’d always heard that being up there was outstandingly beautiful, and now I know that it’s true.

Lots of up. I took a few hours in the afternoon to do the walk and enjoyed it but there was no special appeal. The scenery was nice and one could go at any pace but the trail was a fairly constant upward hike and you end up in a residential area with minimal appeal. Do it if you have time--and perhaps in the morning--but not a "must" in my book.

They don't call this the King's Walk for nothing!. Do it before the sun rises and be rewarded with views of Mt Agung and Mt Batur. You get great exercise, absolutely out of the hustle and bustle of Ubud, walk through an artist's village, rice paddies and end up at Karsi Cafe for a mango lassi in one of their little private huts with a view. Spectacular start to the day - look out for the sign to Ibah or Kiradi Spa - just after the cutting and before Campuhan Bridge as you walk out of Ubud. And if you don't fancy the walk back (it is not a round trip sadly) - just hire a car!
Lovely views. Lovely walk and views. If you are going mid-day, make sure you have a hat, sunscreen and water as there isn't much shade along the walk.

Great 1/2 of the walk. Well it is very good walk at the beginning. You go along the ridge and enjoy beautiful views of two river valleys. After that you come to busy jungle road and the trip is not as enjoyable - better to return back.
Gorgeous Walk. Don't miss this if you are in Ubud. It is a lovely walk into the countryside - just remember water, a hat and insent repellent.

Great way to explore around Ubud. We did the walk with a guide from Kayumanis Private Villa & Spa in Ubud, They dropped us at the start and picked us up at the end. Great way to see some rice fields and village life around Ubud. It's a very easy walk with plenty of photo opportunities along the way.

Best massage in Ubud on the Campuhan Ridge. A gorgeous walk, especially when you get up high past the temple... great views along both sides and interesting to see the beauty just behind the main road on the left side. Ubud is so busy now it's heartening to know there are still quiet places just a short walk away from the centre. Lots of cute little family homestays going up now, and a couple of hotels which are thankfully set way back from the road and the ricefields. Still plenty of village life scenery; farmers in the ricefields, cows grazing and chickens roaming about. Karsa Kafe is the best place to sit and drink in the view. They are also building a spa which has started operating from one of their villas. I got caught in the rain so went for a massage to kill some time. It was awesome! Better than anywhere else I've been for massage in Bali, and I've been to many! And had a long hot shower afterwards. I didn't continue the long round trip; just came back to Ubud the same way, which was an easy downhill stroll. Definitely a must do walk!

A beautiful walk. A beautiful walk. Strongly suggest you take a taxi or driver to the start of the walk at the top and walk down. We went to "Bridges" restaurant afterwards for lunch which is very near by and was delicious. Have the Bridges lemonade!

The best views in Ubud, lovely walk. We went at mid-day so it was a bit hot but still really worth it for the views. You walk up along a narrow ridge right between two rivers and there's long green grass all around. Across the river on one side are some buildings, but the other side is completely empty with rice paddies in the distance. A must-see.
A great walk. This was a really easy and interesting walk with a great cafe at the half way point. We were dropped by our hotel at the cafe Karsa and from here it was a downhill walk.

Give it a try. After the Mt Batar sunrise trek this was literally a walk in the park. Besides the first part that is the hill to get to the ridge the rest is an easy going, paved path.We left early (6.30 a.m) to beat the heat & was glad we did. The only thing was once we got past Karasa Kafe we didn't quite know how much further to go, as our hotel told the track just leads to villages. But it becomes quite a main tarred road, so after 1/2 hour of that we turned around & headed back. Enjoyable & would do on regular basis but like a previous reviewer said if looking for rice paddy walk go up to Jalan Kajeng, my favorite sunrise walk .

Nice to get away from busy traffic. Nice quiet walk very scenic pretty flat not too strenuous We did it mid day quite hot but a few shady areas and places to buy drinks along the way. Nice to get out of the busy town.

Well Worth It!. We decided to do this hike early in the morning however it was still hot hot hot as it tends to be in Bali. It is easy on the feet, with a paved track and not too many stairs to walk up and down. Half decent shoes will do the trick. The views are quite breathtaking and also walking through the villages makes you feel as if you are seeing the "real" Bali. There was one very steep hill on the road back into Ubud so beware! On the way back into Ubud there are many shops and restaurants to break the journey. Recommend this hike if you are even semi fit, just take your time and enjoy what is has to offer.
good place for walking in peace. good for walking in peacefull place like that, nice remember with my family walking around here.. nature is all around you and you can feel it on your skin

Feeling energetic?!. There is really nothing to dislike about this hike. It is definitely a great way to burn a few calories and see the countryside. The temperatures are always hot in bali so be prepared by bringing water with you. At the top of the ridge there is a café that you can get some fluids and have a rest.

Amazing view. I would recommend this little trekking to everyone. The view is amazing and you can stop on your way to visit art galleries and sip a fresh fruit juices. For those who don't like walking too long you can retrace your steps and go back to Ubud by the same path. For other (like me and my partner), you can walk through little villages to go back to Ubud. The only down side is that you have to walk on the road as there is no path for pedestrian so it can be a bit dangerous.

Wonderful.So scenic.. Loved everything about this walk.Started off near the Campuhan Bridge , few steps to start with, then in to the rice fields between 2 rivers.An easy walk to the end and back, plenty of interesting scenery.Stopped at a little warung halfway along the ridge and enjoyed the best freshly squeezed apple juice I have ever had, whilst watching the women in the rice paddied.Spoke to quite a few locals selling paintings, eggs, etc. Allow a couple of hours to enjoy the walk and scenery.So close to town but a totally different experience.Do it now before it gets spoilt as new hotels, etc already being built there.

Nice but the Rice Fields Walk is better. We didn't do the entire walk based on the reviews here, and instead just walked to Kafe Karsa and back on the same route. The route on the ridge is very nice with views of 2 river valleys. We started out early (around 8am) and didn't really break out a sweat until the walk back. However we much prefer the rice fields walk starting from Jalan Kejang. That walk gave a much better view of local life, whereas this walk felt a bit touristy especially once you reached the top of the ridge with the souvenir shops and expensive villas.
TWO RIVERS MEET. Exciting, haunting and oh so envigorating for the soul. Nothingto dislike about this outing.......will return and take some familywith me.

A great walk to start the morning. We tackled the walk up Campuhan Ridge before the rain arrived mid afternoon. The scenery along the way is impressive. We enjoyed stopping off for a juice at the warung overlooking the rice fields at the top. For the walk back to Ubud we chose the road, which was longer and hillier than the Ridge walk. Heading back up the Ridge this week and will walk back down the way we came.
beautiful green walk. nice walk here or even with bike, peace and lot of bird around, if you are in ubud mustly come at this place

Don't start at Iban!. I had researched this walk as I didn't want to use a guide. A lot of reviews suggested starting at Iban Resort. We got a taxi from our hotel to Iban, the driver asked if we were doing the walk, he explained starting at Iban meant the walk would be mostly uphill. He ended dropping us a 10 minute walk from Karsa Kafe. This meant our walk was mostly down hill and got a lovely breeze on us. We also didn't have to walk on the busy road into the track. Although the walk was shortened it allowed us more time to stop and enjoy our surrounds. A drink and feeding the fish at Karsa Kafe was lovely then we ventured on looking at some local craft and paintings. The ridge walk was absolutely stunning,so many locals to stop and chat to along the way and many young couples sneaking a kiss in the shade but still very quiet and secluded. The main development we noticed was the development before the bridge. Remember just keep going straight ahead then follow the path until you reach the bridge.
Stay on the ridge.. The first part of the walk, that part that is not on a road is great, although you do build up a sweat. The end portion is mainly on a fairly busy street and is not that magical.
Splendid. Very much enjoyed an early morning walk in this spot, wonderful views, and fresh air. Highly recommended. Go before it's too hot.

Don't forget your money. We went on this trial with a guide from our resport but no-one thought to tell us to take money. There were very disappointed artists and egg painters and cafe owners along the way. However, even if you just want to walk, it's not a wild adventure but a pleasant one wandering through the rice fields.

Really wonderful walk into local countryside near to Ubud centre. If you like easy hiking this is definitely worth doing, an easy 2 hour or so walk close to the west-side of Ubud's centre - see my map in the attached photos. You see some wonderful countryside and best of all visit the very lovely Karsa Kafe for lunch as a reward for your efforts, under an hour from the main road.Start from the Ibah Hotel (see my pics) on the west side of Ubud centre, go down the steep pathway to the river on the left-hand fork, follow the sign over the bridge/river and then walk up the path (its a bit scruffy to begin with, but gets better as you climb higher up)It then opens up to the ridge and the views are just great, see my pics. About a kilometre or so in you'll see the Karsa Kafe on your left, stop here for lunch, it has really good cooking! Top price for a dish is R35,000 (approx GBP £2.30 !) - note it closes by 4-5pm.If you continue the walk to the main road after the cafe, about 10-15 mins, then this is the end; note that there are some lovely terraced rice fields to the left side. Then turn round and return to Ubud on the same trail. Enjoy!

Out and Back. Take the ridge walk, but don't turn left at the road that takes you down to the river and up the other side. Turn around and go back the same way. Much safer than walking on the narrow, winding road.

Easy walk. Beautiful scenery, through the countryside, we managed it with 4 children in tow, we walked into Ubud, had breakfast them walked back as we are staying in the village. It does get hot if not cloudy but it's a very easy walk and well worth it!

Brick road to the Emerald City. The trail is really hidden from the main road but it could find it, you're in for a treat!Unfortunately there's not enough information, nor you could google map it. Hence, I've drawn up a map so with the "walkthrough" you won't be constantly doubting you we're on the right path like I did.When you're strolling west coming downhill from Jalanraya Ubud, look for a big stone signage: Ibah Suites, Restaurants & Spa. Look closer and the little signage pointing towards the hill is actually hidden underneath Ibah's menu! Follow the steep trail downhill, walk cross the bridge, it will lead you to a temple. You cannot enter its main yard as it is under renovation. Outside the temple towards the end of the trail there're steps taking you down to the river which is also worth a visit. The ACTUAL campuhan trail, however, starts before the bridge on your right. The alternative trail will take you around via the side of the temple on your and roaring river on your right. Do be cautious of the condition of the trail due to the on-going construction, it get slippery after rain or simply obstructed by construction materials.If you're able to walk around the temple side you will immediately see a stretch of grey brick road laid in front of you. Follow the (grey) brick road and you're on your way to the lush Emerald City!Do:Allow yourself half a day to explore the trail;Wear comfortable clothing, a good pair of walking/running shoes;Bring a bottle of water;Observe the local weather come rain or shine because you will be fully exposed to it throughout the entire walk;Use sunscreen, insect repellent and etc;Pace yourself - the trail spans 3km (to the peak) and 7km (full circuit);Bring camera - every scenery is wallpaper worthy!
Decent views close to Ubud. A tad bit of an uphill walk,but once you get up there,decent views of surrounding hills/river etc...bring your water,hot walking

if you are going to do the entire walk: circuit, give yourself plenty of time as you walk back through lovely villages.. just scenically beautiful, too much development happening .. buildings popping up like mushrooms, and spoiling the large vista's of rice fields.

A great way to start your day. The nearly 10km walk pass through some really beautiful scenery and quaint villages. Must bring a good camera to capture those beautiful scenes. The walk built up our appetite to a scrumptious breakie at the resort. One of the top things to do in Ubud to those who enjoy a good workout with a view!!!
Spectacular way to view Campuhan. we walked this from the northern end , back into Ubud, so it was mostly downhill and its a really lovely way to explore the connecting villages.

Good walk. Followed the Lonely Planet guide, which was pretty good for the most part, but lost the trail at Moziac - ended up being taken off route by a local guide, which added kms to route and we saw enough rice paddies with rice at every stage of development. The first part of the walk is really good, with lots of different views and a good stretch of the legs. Following the Lonely Planet guide, unfortunately, takes you back mostly by main roads so not so pleasant.

beautiful walk. This ridge runs between two rivers. There are currently no houses or hotels as you go up the hill but it may not stay this way for long. Go see it while you can. There are beautiful views to each side of the walk. At the top of the hill there are art galleries along the road to stop and have a look at. There's a cafe or two and views of rice fields as well as a traditional village. If the sky is clear, you can see majestic volcanoes in the distance to both the north west and north east. Beautiful!

A delightful gem of a trail - if you can find it.. It was rather difficult to locate the start of this trail from Ubud town. Walk out of town towards Jl Campuhan. It's on a driveway on the right hand side after a downward incline on the road that's flanked with stone walls (if you see Murni's Warung on the left, you've passed it and need to back track about 50m). This walk is great in the early mornings or whenever the sun isn't blazing. Wear track shoes - inclines can be steep at points. Love the view from the top of the ridge and Karsa Kafe with its views across verdant paddy fields. We thumbed a lift from some farmers/workers in a truck heading back towards Ubud afterwards. Everyone in the villages is really friendly. Give yourself a good 4 hours for this walk.
Beautiful for Ubud.. It is a short pretty walk. But while I was there, they were renovating the temple and it was a mess at the bottom of the hill with all of the construction.

One of my favorite walks in Ubud (Bali). I did spend many times in Klub Kokos, a small resort outside of Ubud, close to the village of Bangkiang Sidem. Everytime when I walked from Klub Kokos to Ubud, using the Campuanridge path, I was impressed by the beautiful views and special atmosfere. It is one of my favorit walks in Bali. Special tip: drink a cappucino in the IBAH-hotel at the end of the path when you enter Ubud.

On foot. I did not do the full Campuhan Ridge Nature walk, but focused on the shopping area. There is a beautiful, steep little street, taking you back towards the old bridge. Along the way I found some nice shops selling Batik clothes, back-packs, food, and even Spa's.One aspect that jarred in various locations in Ubud was the habit of dumping waste, plastic bags etc in the rivers or down the side of spectacular ravines.

There is a much nicer walk trough the rice fields!. We only liked the first part of the walk, uphill and overlooking the valey. When you reach the not really authentic but more touristics houses with galeries, you can return by the same road. Or walk further till you reach the nice cafe in the ricefield.But...we much more loved the really authentic walk beginning just in ubudcenter, into the ricefields, and real farmers and authentic vieuws., as we did 4 years ago.

Must do in Ubud. My partner and I followed the Lonely Planet path and it took us about 5 hours return as we stopped at many shops along the way. The good: - the first part of the walk up the ridge is beautiful and quiet - loved the kafe at the top overlooking the paddies (spring rolls were yummy! and the huts you can sit in are amazing) - loved the art shops in the villageThe not so good: - the last half of the Lonely Planet walk is closed (instead of walking through the paddies, you keep walking along the busy road), so Lonely Planet needs to do an update.  - uou walk along a very busy and narrow street on the way back, and it felt a little unsafe, but I suppose it's part of the experience!Overall, I would recommend it on a cooler day if possible. We did this during the hottest time of day! Be sure to bring lots of water...and a sweat towel! :)

Lovely scenery, hot walk.. I forced myself to make this walk even though I had Bali belly, and it was worth it. Don't forget your camera. Best time is at/before dawn, and make sure you take plenty of water with you.

Great! Get there before the developers do.... We've done this walk more times than I can remember and it's always a memorable family outing. Unlike the rice field walk around Subak Sok Wayah the main part of the walk remains untouched by the developers, though how long this will last - who knows. Walking from Ubud out towards Cafe Karsa the path ends in a set of steps and a few houses. Or at least it does at the moment. In 2013 a huge 43 roomed hotel plus chalets and spas is due to open and the entrance road will be between these houses and Cafe Karsa - so the cafe Karsa is doomed as a quiet, rice field retreat. To accomodate this development an enormous section of the rice terraces in the valley have been gouged out. Once this development is finished the pressure will be on to extend the road across the Campuhan Ridge and into Ubud...
Hot and exhausting but worth it!. Good track, uphill so quite tiring, but wonderful views. And the reward was finding Cafe Karsa at the top - great juices.

A great walk. After enjoying several jam-packed days full of rafting, cooking classes and cycling, I was searching something to do in Ubud that wouldn't require forking out rupiahs. I found this walk recommended on TripAdvisor so one morning me and my boyfriend went for a stroll.We started from the main street with Ubud market on our left hand side and we just kept walking straight outside of town. Walk until you see Ibah Spa on your right. Turn right and there will be a sign pointing you to the 'Walk to the Hill' or something like that. Just follow that signs and you will find the trail easily. There are some shops and cafes on the way in case you get hungry/thirsty. We just brought our own water bottles and snacks so we didn't visit any of the cafes. I don't recommend going in the middle of the day because there is no shade and it gets very hot. I would imagine early morning (5-6 am) to be the best time to go.Overall it's a beautiful walk and an easy (and free!) way to get away from the hustle and bustle of Ubud town for a few hours.
Breath of fresh air. We went early morning and it was delightful before ths sun became too hot. Many locals walking their dogs or jogging. Lovely views over the rice paddies.

a stroll into Bali. The full three hour + round trip will give you a wonderful peek into Balinese life - through villages, past family farms, dance centres and temples and chooks and dogs and kids going to school. all of it in a stunningly beautiful part of Bali. And of course you'll pass the hotel strip from the Campuhan bridge up to Senggiggi(?) turn-off road - past our favourite restaurant (Indus), hotel (Ananda) and spa (Bliss). All of this in what is really a stroll rather than a trek :)

beautiful views. Choose early morning for the walk. We walked about 4 kms, met friendly locals along the route, saw a wedding from distance, had coffee in a cafe/gallery in rice fields, and on the 4 km way back bought chilled water at another cafe/gallery.

One highlight of our trip. Such a beautiful walk along the lush greens of ubud. A little difficult to find at first but once you are on the path you just have to to follow the path. Some of the art that was being sold along the way was absolutely beautiful, it was just a shame that the owner couldn't be found so that we could buy some,

Beauty everywhere you look.. A favorite walk, to restore the soul. Don't leave Ubud without this treat of peace and tranquility. It's a steep climb, not much at the top, but buildings going up everywhere in Sebali village at the top.

just follow your lonely planet... Great tour, beautiful views! During the walk you pass along a small place where you can eat and drink something. I don't remember the name of the place but it offers an amazing view and is very peaceful. The food and drinks are also very good and have a good price. (Very good nasi !!). The last part of the tour was a little bit dangerous because we had to walk near a busy road with lots of up and downs. And didn't look like we were supposed to walk there. It felt like walking on a high way :-) Beautiful views on the rice terraces and a good way to explore the less touristic side of Ubud. I really recommend it. Tip: make sure you bring water with you.

An evening or morning hike. A beautiful walk, although a little exposed during the heat of the day. Don't do this walk at night! Too many barkey ankle-biting dogs who will pursue you through the villages.

The simple things in life....... We like to walk at home so it seemed a natural thing for us to do.Very enjoyable. Got a bit lost at the end, but just asked the locals to direct us, no problem. Took us 1hr 45 min. Taxi dropped us off at Campuhan Bridge and pointed us in the right direction. Walked to our resort - Payogan Resort and Spa.

Natural beauty and easy walking. Ubud central is now a busy hectic place but 5 minutes from the centre of town you can find a wonderful walk up through alleyway and then amongst rice and vegetable fields. Views of the distant Agung Volcanoe could just be seen on the day we walked. A stop off at the rrganic farm for a fresh fruit juice or bite to eat is also good. It was disappointing to see however the large excavation occuring on the side of the valley for more massive resorts :-(

Lovely coconut drink at 6am. This is a special place. When I was walking there early one morning, a man spotted me from a coconut tree, ran down and presented me with a lovely coconut drink. He wanted a few coins to buy coffee which I was pleased to give him.

Unforgettable!. Easily the highlight of my trip to Ubud! The walk is gorgeous, taking us to gorgeous rice fields and beautiful sights. I personally didn't find the walk or slopes challenging (and I'm not that fit!); more that the heat from the afternoon sun was trying. But still we eventually came upon a rest stop cafe which had huts by the paddy fields and cold drinks. Wonderful adventure!

Beautiful views along this ancient trail.. This walk is one of the better around Ubud, and takes you past one of the larger and older Temples in the area at the meeting of the rivers. The views along the ridge are absolutely stunning. The walk will also take you through a traditional village, and there are plenty of small art galleries along the way. I suggest wearing running shoes or sturdy footwear as the roadway is very rough, the trail is steep, and can be a bit treacherous and slippery when wet.

A GREAT WORK OUT. A beautiful hike up and around an amazing ridge. Go early before it gets too hot. Start your walk at the Camuhan River just next to the Ibah Hotel you can stop at Fly Cafe for a coffee than continue down back to Ubud.
Very good. Very pleasant walk to go on early morning before it gets too hot. Wear a hat! Nice views and not spoiled yet.

great views. A really beautiful view of ubud surrounding area and so peaceful. A wonderful walk which gets you away from the busy road and into real countryside. There were a lot of organic farms and local cafes which sold fresh juices

Great views. This walk had lovely views and got away from Ubud town itself and out into the countryside to see rice terraces and little villages. The view and smoothies at Karsa Kafe were famastic as a stopping off point.

Don't miss doing this!. Highlight of our trip to Bali. Great photo ops all along the hike. You will see old Bali with farmers doing all kinds of work. Also, was nice to just walk right from downtown Ubud. Ubud is pretty dirty with trash and this walk is clean and very enjoable. A must do!

Nice walk, pretty views. Just a nice walk really. We went to Indus restaurant on the way back which was great. We also bought some little minature painting from a guy painting by the side of the path.

Peaceful beauty a few minutes from the crowds of Ubud. Great photo op. A nice quiet walk through nature. Highly recommended. Also, it's free! Puts you right near/in Penestanan which is a great place to do some souvenir shopping away from the crowds in town.

A must do. I've done this walk twice now and will do it when I come back to Ubud. Amazing views, lovely people to talk to along the way, a great cafe to break your journey. No Bintang singlets. One of my top "must do's" in Bali.

A must!. This is our fourth trip to Ubud and our first time doing this walk! Didn't know it existed. Wow, what a great way to start the day....amazing views, the colours are spectacular. Go at your own pace and enjoyed the scenery, lotus flowers and the lush green rice paddies. Plenty of places to stop on the way and have refreshments and see some wonderful art.

Short taste of rice field perfection. Easy to get to from central Ubud and gives a good overview of Ubud life. A cafe with open air rooms floating on a pond was a perfect stop for a Bali coffee. We continuted walking on the road to Taro through rice fields and forest. No need to go that far unless you really want a long 15k walk with a pickup truck as transport back to Ubud.

so close to ubud and so refreshing. easy to do, easy to find, hard to miss if you like just getting out there and doing a walk through the fields..if you keep going you can do a 3 hour walk along the ridge, through a couple of villages, up a very very steep hill and back into Ubud....stopping at Fly cafe for a beer.

Lovely country side and peaceful walk. My family did the Campuhan Ridge Walk and it was really lovely and peaceful. From Ubud Town it is a gentle walk up but then just walking along the top of the ridge. The countryside of rice terraces are absolutely gorgeous. I took many photos of panoramic style. There are heaps of small family run galleries to look through. About 1/3 through there is a guy who was selling fresh coconuts to drink. Once on the other side of the ridge there is a section where you walk along the road lined with shops. In this section we had the most magnificent shaved icecreams at a pink shop called Eses - apparently it is a Japanese style icecream but it was just fabulous. After the partial road walk you cut back into the rice paddies just past Mozaic restaurant or at least that is what the Lonely Planet book says. There were about four families also walking around near the Mozaic restaurant trying to find where you cut back into the rice paddies but no one could find the track again. Several of the taxi drivers said it is because its not there any more due to development of hotels, at first we thought this was a way to get us into a taxi but alas I now think it is very true that the development of hotels has taken away the last part of this great walk.Well worth the walk - I loved it.Lou

Great views - not too taxing. We enjoyed a walk along the ridge and the great views from the path. Once at the top, we stopped for a beer and a rest at the little bar/cafe that overlooks the rice paddies. It has a lovely breeze which was great after the warm walk up the hill. (They also offer a lift back to town for anyone who can't face the 3km walk back.)The walk is steep in places but it's paved and there are trees at the top to shelter from the sun.

Beautiful rice field walk, plus art galleries and good food. We were staying in the village of Penestenan and accessed the Campuhan ridge by climbing up the hill to a swanky hotel on the side of the river gorge. There we turned left following the “Up the Hill” sign, and snaked our way up and along a small paved cement path into the hills. The path travels up and along a ridge between two river gorges, one side of which is planted with rice and the other with villas and hotels terraced down to the riverbed. After a walk of half an hour or so we reached a small village at the crest of the hill, seemingly every house of which belonged to artists and all selling paintings, carvings, and drawings from their home galleries (as well as renting bikes, motorbikes, etc). Some of these places were very elaborate and also contained rental units; others were much more modest in scale. As we walked along we could hear the hordes of ducks honking in the fields as they nosed in the cut rice for critters to eat. We’d worked up a sweat from our climb and so stopped at one small home and gallery for a beer and to admire the view. While there, we had a look at all the paintings on display and decided to purchase one small painting on canvas of a barong dance and a stylised drawing of three figures dancing. Prices for the paintings here are incredibly inexpensive and if we had untold funds and untold room in the bags, we would probably have bought more. Further along the path we came to a newly-opened cafe situated in a lotus pond with a view over rice terraces, a perfect spot for lunch, after which we continued through more artists’ villages and onto a main road. I had thought that this particular path returned via a loop to town but it became increasingly obvious as we went further along that it did not. Several cycle tour groups had passed us on the way and, luckily, one small group was just loading up the bikes to return to Ubud as we approached. After inquiring about how far the road went, and realising that, at 20 km, it was too far to finish that day, we asked for a lift back to Penestanan which they were kind enough to give us at no charge – huzzah! This walk is highly recommended. The rice fields in Bali are the most incredible bright green that I’ve ever seen. And the contrast between the green of the fields, the darker green of the palm trees, and the blue of the sky is magical. See pictures here: http://lmaclean.ca/2011/10/ubud-rice-field-walk-and-more-art/

A Beautiful Walk in a Beautiful Place. Many people come to Ubud for the cultural activities that abound there, and the art that spills out onto every street. It's probably the best place in Bali, especially if you're not particularly into the beach scene. Walking around Ubud and ducking into quaint shops, bargaining at the pasar- village market, having a stroll through the Monkey Forest, and visiting the palace and many temples are wonderful experiences. However, they almost all pale in comparison to the wonderful experience of taking a walk on the Campuhan Ridge in the early morning. This walk starts in "downtown" Ubud and takes you along the ridge that begins at the confluence of the Wus 1 and Wus 2 streams. In fact, Campuhan means to mix- so where the waters mix, or meet. It's a slightly steep climb at the beginning but should not be a challenge for most people. Quickly you are up on top of the ridge that separates the two streams of Wus and you are greeted with beautiful views across both canyons. The only downside is having to look at all the expensive villa hotels clinging to the west side of the walk. Huge ugly satellite dishes- so satellite tv can be received by the villas- are not nice to look at no matter where you're at. However, the east side view is beautiful as you look across to the terraced rice fields. The ridge walk itself is not in the rice fields but through the tall grasses that the Balinese often use to make alang alang, the thatched roofs you see on their temples and homes. If you're lucky to have clear view you 'll have a chance to see Mount Agung off to the east and other mountains in the central part of Bali to the west. However, even if you don't have those views you will have the memories of a spectacular walk in a beautiful place to take home with you and keep forever.
